column36: Provided more details about the specific locale in which I would be teaching
column46: Getting to know the cohort. Fun openers and activities helped to add cohesiveness to the group and support a team based environment

column36: More concise communication. Or one final email with crucial info because we receive so many.
column46: The diverse seminars led by community members and volunteers.

column36: If possible send predeparture information sooner
column46: Spanish class  When sept. Cohort volunteers came for different topics

column20: I considered Peace Corps as well.
column36: I would have liked more site specific information. For instance, more information about the school we would be working for. I know this is difficult considering placements happen later. However, I would have liked to learn about the company I would be working for before getting here.
column46: We have very attentive and personable field staff who took the time to listen to feedback in order to make sure we have the most effective orientation experience.

column20: WorldTeach China was something I also considered, but I did not compare multiple programs.
column35: I liked having a set checklist to complete before departure. It was nice to have specific steps to take before coming to Ecuador.
column36: I wish we had been given a better sense of what the orientation would be like. The days were really long and some sessions were not as important to me as others. We also had to wait a really long time to find out about host families and where we were going to be placed, which was kind of tedious.
column40: I would consider Posada del Maple instead of Casa Jazmin. I stayed in Posada for one night and I liked it a lot better than Casa Jazmin in terms of accommodations. It was also suggested to me that I stay at Posada, even though the accommodations were across the street. I probably would have stayed at Casa Jazmin for the night when I arrived. It would have also been nice to have multiple airport pick ups available because I legitimately could not get a flight to come at 5 p.m. which is why I left the day before and had to arrange taxi and accommodation for myself. It didn't seem like there was any flexibility in terms of pick up and that also led to certain people missing the first orientation dinner because they had later flights. I don't think that was fair or well-planned. It's not the fault of volunteers that many flights were not able to be coordinated around the time that WorldTeach could pick some people up.
column46: Having other volunteers come in and share their experiences  Spanish class  Getting to know my cohort  The weekend trip to Mitad del Mundo and Teleferico

column33: The TEFL certification's marketability. I plan to pursue a career teaching English abroad in the immediate future.
column36: N/A. The U.S. office was communicative and helpful.
column46: Spending a week in Swakopmund, having our day excursion over to Dune 7 near Walvis Bay, and the teaching practicum in Kavango West---we had an amazing host family and the location was perfect.

column36: N/A
column46: Highlights: classroom site visits and MYO visit, meeting with UNICEF

column31: Not all extra costs were shown very clearly. More info would be nice before arriving.
column36: Office was very responsive and I have no complaints of advice.
column46: The group meals were great for team building, and the outings were great to experience Namibia a bit while training. The big highlight for me was the time spent in teaching practice or classroom observation. I think orientation was good to learn about culture and things, but it was hard to learn much about culture or education without talking to locals or doing activities outside our living space. Costs can be an issue but I think it is very important to meet people and have group outings to experience classes or Namibian activities in real life so our training had more context.

column33: I knew I would be teaching math, and TEFL did not seem worth the cost.
column36: I feel I was well prepared, however, a little more information on my site would have been helpful. For example, I'm living on school grounds and was told the school had wifi. Naturally, I assumed the wifi would reach my house but it doesn't.
column46: I thought the cultural training was incredibly beneficial. I enjoyed staying on the traditional African homestead, as I feel it will help me better understand my learners.

column31: Wish there was more information about culture in my pre-departure. Maybe required videos to watch from women, minorities, etc. or about traditions, politics, etc.
column33: Because I would like to be a TA in graduate school
column35: It could have been a lot better. Instead of just recieving a booklet and a book about Ecuador and being told to read it, WorldTeach could have taken us through a deeper understanding through video of the culture, norms, etc.
column36: It would have been really interesting to have a canvas training page where we had to read, watch videos, write about our understanding, etc. about material for our given destination.
column46: Getting to know everyone and Melissa giving time to fill in as Director:)

column35: Prior to departure there were lots of things I was still waiting to know- for example information about my host family in the city I was placed in, information about getting paid, etc- but overall communication was good and I figured I would learn those things in-country.
column36: Weeks after I submitted documents, the volunteer portal would not reflect that the documents had been received. If the office could be more on top of marking documents as received it would help!
column46: Meeting people and getting to know the cohort. The excursions were fun and I learned most about Ecuador through them.

column36: More communication and more planning would have been much appreciated.
column40: Martha was absolutely wonderful but her cooking was really bad. I lived there with two other volunteers who felt the same way.
column46: The cross-cultural information.

column33: The time that was needed to get the certification.
column36: Provided more support to volunteers arriving a little earlier to help with accommodations.
column46: The final dinner at Anaconda and going on the chiva.

column35: I needed my passport back asap because of another trip I was taking before coming to Ecuador. Everyone was very helpful and understanding with this process.
column36: I think it would've been helpful to know about needing to send in your passport from very early on, and also an estimate of exactly how long I would be without it.
column46: Highlights of orientation were Spanish classes and learning about the culture, and excursions. However, in the same way that were were split into different classes based on our Spanish levels, I wish something similar had been done according to teaching experience, when we had sessions about teaching (lesson planning, classroom management, etc.), because I got a degree in Education, and all of that was basically a condensed version of my past 4 years.

column31: Some of the predeparture materials seemed outdated.
column33: Cost was lower than most other programs with TEFL
column35: I felt that there were a lot of details we didn´t know until last minute.
column36: Give more details!!
column46: Spanish classes and the excursions!

column31: Fundraising section is vague and did not seem site-specific. Highlighting real costs would prove valuable to applicants as they try to realistically afford this experience.
column33: Price
column36: Give more thorough information. There seemed to be a heavy reliance on previous volunteers helping answer questions. I found that their responses were not thorough which is understandable because they may be busy. But there was a real missed opportunity to solidify details.
column40: Good, central location. Coordination could be improved. Perhaps having more than one pick up time from the airport or providing volunteers well-vetted drivers.
column46: The one on one check ins were great albeit it seemed overwhelming for staff. The review of Bloom's taxonomy and teaching theory was insightful. The quick change in response to orientation location was impressive.

column36: I'm not sure. I believe they did a very good job.
column40: Since there were two little windows for 40 people there was no fresh air. But we were able to use the site for free so I think it was still worth it. But the lack of fresh air would be my only complaint.
column46: I loved how the staff took in our input and made changes immediately. We had a diversity session that needed improvement and the staff made it a priority to receive input, change their plan, and have another diversity session. Also, we struggled to finish all our session on time, and when the volunteers voiced this issue the staff made it a priority that we finish on time. So the highlight was a thoughtful, sensitive, and respectful staff. Way to go staff!

column27: I asked a couple times about sending in actually visa and photos of myself and answers were to clear so I sent a few things late.
column36: Can't think of much.
column40: More food needed from host.
column46: Had a blast going to some of the sites around Quito. The staff really tried to accommodate by switching up the scenery. I think some of the politically correct sessions could be saved for a different thing. I wanted to learn how to teach.

column13: In the process of making a YouTube and a blog. Will share when I have information
column20: North American Language and Culture Assistants' Program (Spain)
column36: I think maybe answering emails a little faster, but to be honest they were pretty much perfect. So, my "complaint" isn't really saying much.
column46: Being able to be with all the volunteers and getting to build relationships and bonds before being sent to our permanent sites.

column31: there was confusing information that was no longer true

column36: nothing specific
column46: thought outside speakers best

column27: Very efficient,clear, and helpful. Was most straight forward out of all the other sites/programs i researched.
column31: Helpful overview, was right amount of info!
column36: I cant think of anything!
column46: How world teach staff really took into account our feedback throughout orientation, and acted on what we suggested. Also practicum was very helpful.

column36: I think they did a great job with communications and materials. It would have been helpful if they had sent some materials more than a week before departure, so that we could have time to digest the information and prepare accordingly.
column46: I enjoyed the outdoor excursions: visiting TeleferiQo, visiting Mitad del Mundo, and trying salsa dancing. I also appreciated when we had guest speakers come to talk to us.

column36: More information about what it means to live with a host family.
column40: I was placed with my Quito host family with 3 other cohort members. I felt that being part of a group of 4 made the initial transition much more comfortable. I always had someone to talk to about what was going on.
column46: I enjoyed the time I had to interact with other members of my cohort. This, more than the introduction to teaching, helped me build an initial community of friends.

column35: The TEFL process was a little unclear in what was needed prior to departure.
column36: There was a lot of vagueness in the aspects of the levels of education we would be teaching, and with that the sense of what to pack and prepare for becomes very unclear and stressful.
column46: Orientation was amazing, the coordinators here made sure that we were getting the best training and cultural connection as possible. However, it was very rushed and condensed due to time restrictions so I don't think that we received the full potential training training that could have been provided.

column27: One of my biggest concerns is that the admissions process is not holistic enough. I say this because I have met a lot of volunteers here that told me they lied on their application. In addition, I have met a number of volunteers that should clearly not be here. A lot of them are simply here because they followed their significant other, simply want to party and travel, or just don't know what to do with their lives so they went abroad--in other words, they have no genuine interest for teaching. For instance, there was a group of individuals here that had pictures on FB where they were dressed as "Mexocans" for Halloween. How could worldteach allow for people like that to go into a Latin American country to teach? I guess what I'm trying to say is that it's easy to fake a persona over an hour interview and some paperwork, there should be a method that filters out these applicants.
column31: I really did not find the Fundraising Guide helpful. It had a lot of information that really did not lead to anything. Kind of like listening to a really boring song.
column33: The cost. I had to think if it was worth it to do the certification, or if having the money in Ecuador would be best. Hope I made the right decision.
column35: The U.S. office always responded to my emails promptly and in a very professional way. At first, I was very impressed with the program, until I met the actual Ecuador staff... I would no longer recommend the program, but I'm sure there is a section where I can write about that.
column36: I think the U.S. office could have given more information about the sites themselves. In addition, I think the office could have provided us with contact information of volunteers that were in Ecuador at the time. Just to get a better feel for the program.
column40: The 30 minute bus ride from my host's house to the site of Orientation was the only thing I did not like. Besides that, she was an excellent host that made the transition into a new country very easy and enjoyable. She is a wonderful woman.
column46: Going to El Teleferico was kind of cool.

column27: I love the list of things to do on the application page.
column31: I successfully fundraised around $2500
column33: Value of TEFL Certification in the future; improving my credentials.
column36: Because so many of us were landing the night before the program start date, it would have been nice to move the program start date up.
column46: The variety of activities planned, including salsa classes, Spanish classes, and excursions to locations like Mitad del Mundo. This variety offered a sneak peek into how we can spend our time here.

column33: already had it

column27: Some things were not made clear such as the fact we would have to pay if we are ill.
column36: Nothing apart from maybe relate the fact we would be financially obligated if we were sick, the fact that orientation would be a month's worth squeezed into 2.5 weeks, the fact that creativity appears to be limited due to the CEC manual requirements of teaching staff.
column40: We were not told initially there would be 7 of us in a 3 bed apartment but this was due to family unforeseen circumstances
column46: Good skills taught

column31: I did not do any fundraising. Had I, I imagine the fundraising guide would have been useful.
column33: I wish to continue working in Language Education.
column36: I cannot think of any suggestions at this time. The process went smoothly for me.

column35: Heather was very helpful and also jays monday messages

column36: Provided a better explanation of what to expect during orientation.     Provide a clear statement of how our contracts for the school year will be handled and that by signing on with WorldTeach the contracts with the schools are signed on our behalf prior to entering the country. Provide a copy of the contract when it is signed.
column46: Group support and team building activities.     Practicum experience was very useful. I highly recommend it for future use.

column27: The application process was a bit bumpy, especially when certain things kept being put off. Nonetheless, I think WorldTeach staff made it a priority to communicate all information with us as soon as they could.
column31: I did not read WorldTeach Settling Into. I do not remember it being available to me.
column33: I honestly thought I wouldn't be accepted into the program by not obtaining it. Nevertheless, I'm glad I did it because I found the information I learned in the course to be helpful to me now in the classroom.
column36: I think the U.S. Office did a wonderful job of offering support & understanding during time prior to my arrival. I do wish they would have provided an updated packing list. All I found was a general packing list for a WorldTeach summer program.
column46: I thought the highlights of orientation were: 1) the dinners we all shared together as a group-those were lovely & fun, 2) the opportunities created for us all to be able to practice language and learn more about the Chinese culture and 3) the fact that I felt we were given a working & learning environment where we could take our time to adapt to our new surroundings.

column27: I am beyond happy with WorldTeach, the communication and support the program gives is amazing.
column31: I was and still am a bit confused about the refunding of the money that was donated by my extended family.

column36: WorldTeach did an amazing job making sure that I was prepared for my trip.

column33: Required for the China fellowship...

column33: I thought the TEFL certification would be useful when I returned to the US so I can continue to teach in this capacity.
column35: Any questions I had, no matter how big or small, were answered in a clear concise manner and the turnaround was very quick. I am very pleased with the service I received prior to departure.

column40: Even though we had small things like the toilet leaking, it was minute compared to the overall accommodations.
column46: Apart from learning about Health and Safety, Culture, Classroom Management etc., we also had speakers who were foreign English teachers. The gave us a good insight on what teaching English to Chinese students was like and what to expect, they also provided us with good tips. However; the overall highlight for me was practicum. I was face to face with the students and teaching. I got to see what worked and what didn't. It was exciting and eye opening.

column40: It doesn't matter the hotel room, it's hard to live out of a bag for 3 weeks. The hotel was fine and effective for what we needed it to be. If the price is fair, I'd suggest booking it again in future years. There probably aren't too many other convenient options either.
column46: Practicum was extremely rewarding and a great prep for facing a thousand students on our own. Chinese class! Laoshi Jessica was a phenominal resource. column36: I found a lot of conflicting information online regarding radiation levels on Marshall islands. column27: A few of the forms were outdated. There were a lot of mistakes and not up-to-date information. These issues were cleared up once I inquired further with the Program Director, but he said that the forms had been wrong for awhile. It could save a lot of his time, and the applicants time, for
column31: A few of the forms were outdated. There were a lot of mistakes and not up-to-date information. These issues were cleared up once I inquired further with the Program Director, but he said that the forms had been wrong for awhile. It could save a lot of his time, and the applicants time, for the materials to be updated. Especially the forms we had to submit.
column33: Reputation and cost.
column35: There could be better communication from Field Staff about things to expect once here. Like, don't bring an iphone--the SIM cards don't work in it. Etc.
column36: Communication about site placement sooner would be nice, but I understand the difficulties since they work with the Ministry on placements.
column46: I really enjoyed the day trips, they helped us get out of our orientation site and start getting to know the country. I think it would be good to have one of those sooner after arriving.

column36: Better and more specific packing lists. Provide more accurate information about what is available and what is not on site, including prices. Packing for a year is difficult, it's even more difficult doing so almost blindly or to an incorrect or inapplicable list.

column35: Prior to leaving and during the admissions process, it was difficult to get any clear answers from anyone about the program. The program materials seemed to help, but once we got to the Marshall Islands we learned that many of the things we brought, bought, or prepared for before departure were unnecessary and a waste of time or money because they were either not needed or available here.
column36: Update materials to more accurately reflect what we need to buy, bring, prepare for before coming. For example, all guides said men didn't need pants but after arriving, we learned that men must have pants prior to entering any government building. Be more clear about marriage standards and living situations in the Marshall Islands. Frank and I were concerned for quite some time that we wouldn't be living together or that we needed to do a shot gun wedding to be able to live together here. Turns out that none of that is true and the Marshallese don't even do formal weddings, which would have been INCREDIBLY nice to know prior to coming.
column40: It was comfortable and convenient for a developing country, yes. I have no complaints based on my expectations when I came. However, a cookstove lit on fire 3 time and we rarely had water, both things that could be improved.
column46: Deaf culture day was fascinating and so important for volunteers who don't know sign language or Deaf culture. Also, the cultural orientation sessions were incredibly important. I also loved the outings we did as a group.

column27: The cost of WorldTeach was a factor in my choice, but it was a negative factor. I was looking into teaching English with out an initial fee in Chile and it was difficult for me to pay the starting cost.
column35: Everyone at the WorldTeach office was VERY helpful and answered the millions of questions that I had before moving to Ecuador.
column36: I applied at the last moment and when I was accepted into the program, I did not realize that a lot of documents were already past due! Maybe, during the interview process go over the steps for after an acceptence. I was a bit anxious about possibly being dismissed by the program because of my lateness.
column40: The hostel is very nice and the staff that works there was very nice. It was good that breakfast was included too! However, based on the flights that were offered from major airports in the US it was almost impossible to recieve the free transportation from the airport. Maybe next time wait to see when most people are coming in and make the transportation from the airport to the hostel at that time. I was very worried about taking a taxi from the airport to the hostel.
column46: I really enjoyed the weekend trips that we were able to go on! Keeps those coming.

column27: Things like the visa process were confusing just in their nature, but I was so thankful to have the staff be so responsive, helpful, and timely while I was scrambling to have everything completed without a consistent Wi-Fi connection!
column31: I was so excited to be given FREE materials to read pre-departure!
column36: I wish I could recall what specifically was so confusing, but I remember understanding the visa process and having all of the materials lined up was difficult and I remember there were a couple of misunderstandings of what to send to whom if I wanted WorldTeach to send my materials in comparison to what I had to do if it was after the deadline.
column46: Being able to take Spanish classes and the field trips for sure!

I think future accommodations in Oshakati should be at a different location.  This location lacked cleanliness, the boys kitchen was not in operation, the staff was unfriendly, and there were many bugs (in and outside the rooms).
column46: I really enjoyed getting to know the other volunteers during down times and CCF was very informative and nice to visit.

If they had been, I would have packed differently.
column40: The amount of time we had to spend living in hostels (with 4-5 roommates) was unreasonable. There were not adequate spaces for privacy/decompression. column40: The site was great; however, on our final week of orientation there were seven guys in our hostel. This was a bit much because many people were sick and being in close quarters increases the likelihood of illness. Additionally, another fellow from a separate cohort was allowed to sleep in our room without our knowledge. I felt like this showed a disregard for the security of our belongings because I entered our hostel room with a foreign bag on the floor. A little communication would have been appreciated. Also, this put 8 people in our room while I was ill, so not a highlight of my orientation.
column46: I enjoyed the overview of the Ecuadorian curriculum given by Andres. It was by far the highlight for me because it most matched my interests with wanting to participate in this program.

column36: Longer preparation time, detailed suggested packing list earlier; larger security section with detailed vignettes which may have influenced packing;

column46: Enjoyed meeting fellow volunteers.

column46: Highlights included cultural excursions - the sites chosen for Ecuador were excellent! I also thought the Spanish classes were well-designed, helpful, and gave us good models for language instruction.

column7: If an alternate duration please specify:
column20: I was looking into teaching through Korea's EPIK program, but had started the application process for the Spring 2017 semester too late.
column27: There were quite a few concerns between myself and other members of the cohort about the final stipend amount we'd be receiving, as we all received conflicting information during the application process. I was told it was $150/month, the information pamphlet said $300/month, and another Fellow was told $250. All of this was cleared up within the first few days of orientation, but this type of informational confusion, along with the fact that one Fellow saw the stipend stated within the pamphlet change between the two times he opened the document, gave us a lot of cause for concern. Plus, I could see this type of mistake scaring people away from a long-term overseas program such as this, as there are a lot of scams out there.
column31: Refer to previous page for comments on errors concerning stipend amount within the "Journey to Ecuador" document.
column33: It's part of our Fellowship requirements, though I was already interested in getting a TEFL certification in order to work and travel to other parts of the world.
column35: I think the support was as good as could possibly be expected for a pilot program filled with so many unknowns, including the fact the situation in our schools differs vastly from Fellow to Fellow and is radically different from what even Edificar told us to expect.
column36: Nothing I could think of that would be helpful seeing as the situation here seems to change day-by-day and no one from any side of things (WorldTeach, Edificar, our schools) really have any idea what's going on since all of this is so new.
column40: It was nice but very tightly packed; if myself and my two roommates didn't happen to have very compatible personalities and dispositions, I could see conflict emerging because there was absolutely no personal space or privacy possible.
column46: The meals we had as a group were definitely the best parts, besides that the orientation was such a crash course it was very difficult to enjoy ourselves.

column40: It was great for a small cohort.

column36: More clear that we are responsible for getting our  immunizations prior to departure and/or information about places in Quito, Ecuador that we could visit once in country.

column36: It would have been good to have an idea of how much toiletries, books, etc cost here vs at home. Maybe a comparison sheet that we could look at so we could have a better idea of the essentials we had to bring versus what we could get here.
column46: I loved the trips we were able to take that allowed us to get to know Quito and helped build bonds with our cohort. I also liked the cultural/adjusting sessions that we did.

column27: All home office staff were friendly and helpful in all steps of the process.
column36: Nothing!
column40: My host mom has presented to be a bit pushy with changing payment dates. Additionally, the house is surprisingly constantly dirty. The dogs are noisy, and the atmosphere coming in was a bit strange. She also does not provide nutritious meals; over half of the plate is rice.
column46: I can't seem to think of any.

column36: The packing list could be updated. Reading material related to teaching would have been helpful.

column46: Building strong relationships with my cohort was the best part. I now feel that I have a resilient support network here in Ecuador.

column13: I have not started one yet.

column36: Most of my group got WorldTeach bags with guidebook and a book about travels abroad, however not of us did. I think if the office wants to support their volunteers they need to do it equally.
column40: My host family was great and excited to have us in the family. Delicious and very healthy cooks who was willing to add variation when needed. She understood many cultural differences between the two countries and took that into consideration. I felt instantly safe and wanted.
column46: The overall highlight of orientation was how quickly the volunteers bonded with one another. As a group of 22, it is easy to pair off or create different groups within the group. column36: Helped more with the onward travel ticket and gave more advice on whether TEFL would be truly beneficial or not.

column36: It would have been nice to have our volunteer Facebook group earlier so we could start meeting everyone.

column33: I don't think I will be teaching English again when I get home so I wasn't inclined to opt in for the TEFL.
column36: I think having a Skype date with a current volunteer would have been very helpful!
column46: I think having everyone together and doing lots of activities together was a great way to foster a sense of community!

column31: The book that we received was not engaging or helpful. I was disappointed about this change.
column33: The reduced cost of the certification.
column35: The responses to my queries - both from the Home Office and the in-country director/assistant - were prompt and thorough. I was impressed with their communication.
column36: Send the Lonely Planet Guide Book! I didn't end up bringing it with me for this reason. Aside from being disappointed with these materials, I though the U.S. Office did an outstanding job providing support and assistance prior to departure.
column46: Team-building activities; leading discussions/practice sessions in orientation; practice teaching.

column33: I have a master's degree in speech-language pathology and I am interested in returning to it after this program.
column36: It would have been nice to know our city placements earlier (Quito or Riobamba), but it was not necessary.
column46: I enjoyed meeting the other volunteers and spending time with them. It was also helpful to be on campus where some of us would be teaching. We were able to observe and learn about the community more.

column36: I feel like the U.S. office did an amazing job!
column46: Being about to explore Quito through our weekend outings. Also, being able to bond with my fellow cohort!

column36: WorldTeach did an amazing job
column46: Getting to know the other volunteers and field director. Doing group activities. Meeting other thai teachers and locals

column33: I didn't have time to observe classes before
column36: I had to do research on my own to know about the "proof of onward travel" issue. If I hadn't discovered that on my own, I could have been turned away at the gate for not having a return ticket dated within 90 days. Then when I was checking my bag and the agent asked how long I would be in Thailand, I had to know to say 90 days, because that was as long as our visas were for.
column40: Because the guys were all situated on the first floor, we were always awoken by the first person to go out the sliding door which was very loud, and we were always awoken by the last person to come back in the evenings for the same reason.
column46: Group outings. Unfortunately there wasn't much time for this during orientation, and people in the group often wanted to go do their own thing separately. The dinner on the boat on the last day was fantastic.

column36: Better list of things to bring/ what type of climate to expect/ cultural standards
column46: Group nights with the Field Director/ practicum

column36: Everything was great. Constant communication and flow of information.
column46: Being able to bond with the cohort and staff.

column33: The cost of the certification was a deterrent for me. I was unable to fund the TEFL certification in addition to the cost of the trip.
column36: Adequate support was provided prior to departure.
column46: The highlight of Orientation was being able to perform practicums prior to the start of classes. This allowed me to get past my initial hesitations about teaching and to apply some of the teaching techniques communicated during training.

column36: N/A
column46: Living with other volunteers and getting to know them + our field director

column33: Good opportunity and seemed very organized through WorldTeach.
column35: Great email communication.
column36: Give us a list of teaching supplies we would need- we got this from current volunteers but answers were varied.
column40: My host family is great. The hostel was also very nice.
column46: Being with the group, getting to know everyone, the final dinner, the day trips we took on Saturdays, and feeling super super supported during a period of transition.

column27: N/A
column31: The literature was outdated and was contradicted during orientation.
column35: Much of the general info provided was helpful but some info was clearly outdated and contradicted during in orientation.    Also, in the materials provided we were advised that lunch would be provided for us. It was not until we were in Ecuador were we informed that this was not this case--I don't have a problem with this change in general (and we were presented with very valid reasons for this change) but this info would have been very useful in budget planning ($100s of dollars of the course of the program)--I felt being more upfront with this change would have been really nice.
column36: Accurate pre-departure literature--I believe the literature provided is targeted to the old WorldTeach Ecuador model.
column40: Great job!
column46: The spanish classes!

column27: I applied to WorldTeach Ecuador way earlier than the application deadline. I applied and interviewed in November of 2015 and the communication from then on was excellent. It took much longer than expected to find out if I had been accepted to the program, but The WorldTeach admissions staff were excellent and very helpful when answering my questions through emails!
column31: The book we were given to read before moving to Ecuador wasn't that great. It was interesting and was good to read, but it didn't really tell me what life in Ecuador was like. All it discussed was one couple's process of building a house in a small town in Ecuador. I wish we could have read a book that would have told us more about what life living in Ecuador is like.
column35: Everything was very clear and it was easy to get ahold of the staff if I had any questions.
column36: I wish I could have known the departure date a little earlier, but I understand that this may not have been possible because of communication between the host sites and WorldTeach.
column46: Seminars where we learned about life in Quito!

column27: Everyone was great about answering my emails in a timely manner.
column31: I couldn't download the WorldTeach Journey To and Settling Into documents on my computer directly from the website. Not sure why that was. It wasn't a huge deal as someone emailed them to me and then I was able to download; it was just an added step.
column33: I figured I'm going to be living and teaching in Ecuador for a year, I might well get something extra to show for my hard work.
column36: Nothing comes to mind; everyone was great.
column40: I really like my host -- she's very friendly and welcoming. The only thing I would say is she's gone a lot. Volunteers that need/would like a lot of support and time with their hosts should not be placed here. I consider myself a fairly independent person and even I wish I had a little more time with her.
column46: I thoroughly enjoyed our weekend trips to Mitad del Mundo, Guyasamin Museum and the Centro Historico tour. Spanish was also great, and I'm looking forward to continuing learning.

column31: The book wasn't particularly relevant to a young professional moving abroad. Although it had helpful tips, it might have been more useful to simply get a book about Ecuador and what it has to offer.
column35: Everything came a little late. I've learning that this is the nature of living in South America, but family and friends were very concerned about my impending circumstances.
column36: It would be great to have our information a little earlier!
column46: I really valued the weekend trips! I also enjoyed when WorldTeach invited local guest speakers. The Field Directors were very supportive and informative, you could tell they were doing their best to make things fun and interactive.

column31: Book/novel that was sent wasn't useful. Some volunteers (1 or 2) accidentally also received a guide book of Ecuador. I would have 100% preferred to receive a guide book of Ecuador; that would have been helpful. I did not even open the novel that was sent to me.
column33: Price and credibility.
column36: Packing list available before handover letters were emailed. Would have liked to see a packing list or even handover letters from years prior, months in advanced.
column46: Learning about safety of Ecuador, dance class, and Spanish class.

column20: Working for a private company called English Village
column33: I was required to complete it because China changed their NGO requirements. Originally, I wasn't going to complete it.
column36: N/A
column46: I enjoyed the group dinners. I also appreciated that our Field Director and assistant helped us to order food and provided recommendations. I liked being able to trust that what they recommended was safe and delicious.

column27: smooth and  very clear
column36: Maybe kept us in the loop with news about visas
column40: it was fabulous
column46: teacher training, practicum, reflection

column27: Some work could be done on clarifying what should be brought to china, i.e. the pictures uploaded should be brought to china, photocopies of passport etc. Also applying and receiving the visa seemed like it should of been done earlier (if possible). Overall the application process was clear, but still room for improvement.
column36: See previous comment. Also I would like to point out the MIT free open course on Chinese. This seems nice and it couldn't hurt to reference it.
column46: Pan Nai Nai's lunch was the highlight. We also worked well as a group and formed some nice relationships. The first week was very good in that the field staff took us around as much as they could.

column33: The partnership that WT had with the accredited organization and the discounted certificate offer.
column35: I had a tricky visa situation and the China Director and WT office were instrumental in helping me during this process. I greatly appreciated their efforts, answering my questions, checking in and just walking with me through the journey.
column36: The only thing I can think of is if we had gotten more details/info about our site placement/school prior to departure. I realize part of this issue was because of the transition of the new FD so it's understandable that we got it late.
column40: I really liked that it was located within walking distance of the school, local restaurants and shops, and that it was a well-known enough so that taxi's could drop us off if we explored elsewhere.
column46: Learning about China and the culture, adjusting to the country by staying together in Changsha, meeting/getting to know my teammates, exploring the city/trying to practice Chinese, and teaching during Practicum with the students.

column27: I would have liked more information on things helpful to bring depending on my area of China as well as a projected amount of money necessary for survival during orientation until the fist pay period at the end of September.
column35: I believe it would be helpful to have more human verbal checkups regarding making sure things needed for the visa process are clear.
column36: Examples of lesson plans and language levels bases on grades being taught. For Example :Junior 1's are likely to know...and should be taught ...and Senior 1's are likely to know...
column46: Working in groups on lesson plans

column36: Specifics on cost in China, For example, food, and transportation.
column46: Chinese lessons, practicum, field trips around Changsha, having a roommate in the hotel, and hearing about previous volunteer experience.

column36: Instead of sending various emails of short length, send one informational, newsletter formatted email with links to departure details.
column40: Having the group stay in the same place as the orientation sessions was very effective, although not the most comfortable sleeping situation.
column46: Listening to professionals who have been involved in the community was definitely a highlight. The sessions of teaching and lesson planning were also very helpful before getting into the classroom.

column27: I do feel that the process needs to be communicated in a better way. There is not a lot of  information. There should also be a stronger sense of competition as opposed to the sense that WT takes anyone who applies (which is the reputation I was aware of).
column31: More information would have been helpful.
column36: It would have been helpful to have more information before departure. It would also be helpful to have more communication between acceptance and departure.
column46: I enjoyed all of orientation.  Getting  to know everyone was great, our outings were a welcomed break from the classroom and it was a chance to for friendships with other volunteers.

column36: Given notice of the PRACIS exam
column46: The fun games! And the hike

column36: I felt very prepared prior to departure
column46: Getting to know Shivaun and the other volunteers. I also learned a lot of teaching skills and more about Anerican Samoa culture.

column31: Lots of spelling errors and some outdated information... Could use some TLC!
column33: Not enough time to prepare
column35: The communication was seemingly sparse but now that I'm here I can see why.
column36: Emailed me about what they needed from me instead of me having to email and ask.
column40: If there was a middle option between agree and disagree I would have chosen it.
column46: Bonding with the group, getting to get out of the school and start exploring, having an opportunity to practice for school once we were already here, and the amount of pizza.

column13: Have not yet created one, will notify WorldTeach when I do.
column20: WolrdTeach seemed the best opportunity to teach in China.
column33: Signing up was part of admission into the 2016 program.
column36: In general WT does a great job of tailoring all info to circumstances of program. It is difficult for participants in other countries, WorldTeach can't prepare specific info for applicants from every country. I would only say that where possible visa documents be provided as early as possible, particularly for participants outside US, it makes visa application process a lot easier. I'm not sure how much control WT has over this, though.
column46: Hard to say there were so many, choice of restaurants and introduction into fun things of Changsha (restaurants, smoothies, steamed bun shop etc.) probably tops the list.

column33: The value for the cost. I figure, I will be here anyway so why not gain this certification and perhaps use it to either teach at home or travel further.
column36: The Smart Traveler site does not allow American Samoa as a destination. More info on banking and  phones would be helpful.
column46: The leadership of Shivaun Wolf. She is an amazing teacher and person. I learned so much from her.

column31: Some of the facts in one of the documents are wrong. For example: "a cut from coral will cause coral to grow in your bones." We have asked doctors and local Samoans since arriving and no one has ever heard of that ever happening.
column36: I thought the US office prepared us adequately.
column46: Getting to know the other volunteers.

column36: paid for vaccinations
column46: Shivaun was great,

column27: The only issue I had during the application process was the reworking of the world teach website (was down sometimes when I needed to access information/materials). Otherwise, the WorldTeach administrators I talked with were very helpful and professional.
column31: Other volunteers I've spoken to seemed dissuaded from reading the entirety of the materials, and I think this is because of the length of both Journey To and Settling Into. I would recommend cutting out redundancies between the two if possible in order to remedy this. Admittedly, I think they should have read it anyway. But I still think this would be helpful.
column35: Overall WorldTeach provided very good support. One constructive critique I would offer is that I received many different emails with important information (the information was found in different places). If the important info was contained in a more central way, I think it would have been easier to keep track of everything and been less stressful. For example, I forgot to bring a voided check because of the multitude of emails.
column36: Sent out some preliminary teaching materials/information to go over.
column40: Solid accommodation and lends itself well to orientation training.
column46: Eating together, going on trips around the island, and slowly easing our way into the culture.

column27: Heather was an amazing resource throughout the application process. I can't thank her enough.
column31: I would have liked to know more about the orientation process before my arrival
column35: I was very unsure of what exactly my first month in Changsha would hold.
column36: Perhaps provide a rough outline of what orientation would consist of.
column40: I wish there were some means to decide our roommates after we got to know everyone, but i understand that is basically impossible.
column46: The group dinners were a fantastic way to relax and meet others during the first week. Great locations were chosen and it was an enjoyable opportunity to try all the different foods. I even tried frog for the first time!

column35: The administrators at the main office were incredibly supportive and helpful during the pre-departure stage. Due to timing, I had to change which program I was entering, and they were incredibly accommodating.
column36: Maybe give us access to hand-over letters etc. earlier so that we would have more time to prepare
column46: Getting to know the volunteers and meeting members of the DOE and Samoan community were my highlights. It was really exciting to be immersed in a community right away to connect with people from different backgrounds who were united toward a common goal.

column33: We had to have TEFL certification to teach in Hunan, China this year.
column36: More videos or commentaries from past World Teachers would have been nice.
column46: I really enjoyed forming a bond with the other teachers here. They are now my support system. Practicum, while nerve-wracking, was also very beneficial, and I am truly glad that I was able to step into a classroom for practice before being thrown into a real classroom.

column33: China required it.
column36: A faster visa materials process would have been ideal. I received the letters to get my visa weeks before my flight, and got the visa only two business days before my flight.
column40: Great location beside the park.
column46: Eating out as a group, practicum training, exploring Changsha, and KTV.
Having fun

column33: Price
column36: I had low expectations from previous blogs and everything has worked out great.  Everything pre-departure and orientation exceeded my expectations.  The field director's constant support made my transition much easier.
column40: I was pleasantly surprised at how comfortable the mats were and the fact that some rooms had AC! I was definitely not expecting that.
column46: Getting to know the other volunteers and getting to see the island was fantastic.

column36: More insight from past volunteers on their experience.
column46: Any extra free time, as well as going out as a group for dinner, KTV and excursions.

column33: I did not sign up at first, and then the certification was required by the China program.
column36: I found everything very organized and helpful already. I would probably prefer if there is an Excel file or something like that, an offline checklist for everyone, because there are so many things to keep track of or prioritize (packing, visa application, other documents, orientation, etc.) This one file may come in handy.
column46: Practicum felt like a roller coaster ride, but I was glad that it happened. We had opportunities to work under pressure and to apply what we learned about lesson planning.
